segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Welcome to the annual DEFCON convention. This meeting was held in exciting Las Vegas, Nevada, from July 9th through the 11th, 1999.
This is videotape number 44, how to use the O2K.
A lot of blatantly obvious stuff, so if it's blatantly obvious to you, congratulations and you have a clue.
First thing you would need to do, obviously, is download probably the international version of the O2K, unless you're within the U.S.
And you can get the U.S. version, which comes with the plug-in for triple-desk encryption.
Thanks to the government, we can't let that go outside the borders, and people outside the U.S. are not fortunate enough to have strong encryption on the networks.
CultDeadCow.com or www.bo2k.com will have it live within a few days, and you can download it from there.
First thing you're going to want to do is go ahead and just unzip your archive.
In the past, what would happen would be people would run the server, and they would wind up infecting themselves.
It would automatically delete, and Sordistic was getting flooded with mails saying,
Hey, why doesn't it work? What happened? And it kind of broke on me.
This left a rash of people sitting in IRC with port 31337 open with no password, getting owned left and right,
and a hard drive suddenly getting formatted in the middle of the night for no reason.
This problem has been corrected, so you cannot walk all over yourself.
When you first run the configuration utility, it starts the wizard.
When you get used to the utility, you can also turn the wizard off so you never have to deal with it again.
You very simply walk through, and it selects the executable as it sits in the directory that it's run out of.
You can browse around and have different ones sitting in different subdirectories under different names
and have different ports, encryption schemes, plug-ins, and whatnot assembled for whatever specific uses you have.
You can select that and move forward.
You can move forward.
Woo! Check that one out.
All right.
All ready.
All right, we'll start from scratch.
Okay, we don't have to reboot.
There we go.
You have your choice of TCP or UDP networking.
The original BO ran on UDP, which was less obvious for people with minimal Windows skills to notice.
BO2K, moving forward into a more reliable and robust program that's more geared towards actual network administration, does TCP,
where in an office corporate-type environment, as a LAN administrator,
you don't care if your clients and your, basically, co-workers see what you have going on with their machine
because you're allowed to, and they can just accept it and deal with it.
You're forced to enter a port number, and it will not run until you do.
And being the US version, this already has three DAOs ready to run on it, so we're going to go with that.
And it's recommended you use something at least 14 characters long when you run three DAOs.
And then you can finish it right up, and that brings you into what is the actual configuration utility.
If you turn the wizard off and you run config, this is what you'll be taken straight to.
If you've turned off the wizard and you ever feel the need to turn it back on, you can go into, just click on the button right there in the upper corner,
and it does bring the wizard back.
Once you're inside, you need to select the server that you want to run on.
And right here we already have three DAOs enabled on it, and we're going to go ahead right now and add in BoP,
which will give us remote administration to the actual desktop and being able to take control of the keyboard and the mouse on it.
Moving down on the configuration, and I hate touchpads, and those little pointy sticks.
You have several options under file transfer, and basically these can just be left to sit exactly as they are.
Configuration is pretty straightforward when you get right down to it.
There's a lot of options, and some of them are rather confusing for some people.
If you did not run the wizard, under TCP IO, default port is where you would set it, and we did set it to 2000.
And you can easily just tweak it there later on if you don't ever want to fire the wizard back up.
UDP is the same thing if you're inclined to run that.
13 is just a few of the basic encryption modules, as well as IO, which, again, you really don't need to mess with.
If you're not using 3DES and you're using XOR, this is where you would put in your encryption key for the XOR encryption.
But since we're using 3DES, we can leave that blank right now.
Startup.
Standard networking type is going to be TCP.
In the future, as other DLLs and plugins come available for it that allow you to run over different types of protocols,
you will be able to set something different in there as well.
Binding string is where we're going to 2000.
Command encryption is 3DES.
Authorization we are just going to set at null.
And idle timeout is currently set to 60,000, which is good for all intents and purposes, and you should never really have to mess with that, I would.
Under stealth, we can configure if we want it to run at startup or not.
This is what somebody was asking yesterday if you saw the CDC release about being able to put it on a floppy
or have it set up to run one time and one time only and not have to mess with the read run machine sitting open after that.
And right now it's set to disabled, so if the machine has it set on it, it will not install into the registry and it will not load it boot up.
So you do have that option right there.
If you're doing testing or you don't feel the need to have this sort of delete itself,
you can also have that set to auto delete or not, and by default that is also disabled.
So if you run it on yourself, you're going to have to really check and see if you did or not,
because it's not just going to disappear and give you a clue.
Insidious is an NT-based setting, which we're not really concerned about.
One time path name is how it will display itself both in the registry if it's installed there,
and also this is the file that it installs itself as.
B02K will rename itself in this case to UMGR32 and install itself in the Windows system directory.
We can control if it runs hidden or not, and also we have more NT-specific.
I don't have an NT machine, so we're not really going to get into those too much right now.
Moving further down, the blue folders are your plugins.
Any of the other plugins you add will show up as blue.
TripleDesk has the encryption stream, which we already put in to show some control inside the startup wizard for the configuration.
The Bopeak settings, you can control your default for your resolutions, your network type, where you're binding to,
and this binds to a very high port by default, as does the hijack, the encryption stream, and your authorization.
So it's all pretty straightforward.
When needed at that point, save it.
Yes?
Correct!
Bopeak's default encryption stream is XOR, and because we are using the US version of 3Desk, we do need to change this to 3Desk.
So we can go ahead and just change it right there, save it up, and save our server again.
And, well, that's already setting that one.
You would, correct, normally need to go through and also on hijack, change the encryption stream from XOR over to 3Desk.
So, at that point you can exit it, and hopefully I will be awake by the time the presentation's over.
I have the server set up right here to run on this guy.
And once you have a server running on a client or a set of clients, you can go to VO2K GUI, open it up, and by default you wind up with a blank, untitled workspace.
And you can save, if you have five or seven servers down below that you use frequently, or if you want to break it up departmental for accounting, human resources, administration,
you can run different types of servers with different DLLs for different departments in your company.
And you can save these workspaces and open up individual ones and have everything already set up and saved and pre-configured for each machine.
We're starting a new machine, so we'll just call it VS Server.
You need to put in the IP address of the machine, followed by the port that you have it set to run on.
And we're already set up for TCP, three does, and an OAuth.
And we'll say OK and proceed.
And it comes up and you've already got everything confirmed at the top.
If you need to go back to change anything, you can click right there and it will bring your configuration back up to change your port or your server.
And at this point you will connect, and this machine is going to bring up stuff that doesn't really matter.
And it shows right here, version backup is 2000, 1.0, which shows we are connected.
And starting at the top and working our way down, we have the simpler things that were present in the older VO.
And you can send simple ping packets off to it and you will get them back.
And they are a bit more reliable since they are TCP based.
Query will basically re-query the server as we just did and reconnected,
where it will query the server for all capabilities, which you'll usually find mostly in the form of plugins down at the bottom.
Under the system folder, you can have your fun stuff with rebooting the machine,
locking it up in the event that you have an employee that you happen to find doing something that they shouldn't be,
or somewhere on the network that was improperly secured,
you can lock the machine up to help them from doing anything that they shouldn't be.
You can get a list of any passwords that are present on the machine that have been cached.
And you can also go ahead and pull up the system info.
And let me enlarge this a bit here.
Well, unfortunately, it's not going to get too much better off of the LCD, I don't think,
unless we were to come up a lot closer and then we would shrink them.
But you can still pull up the amount of RAM, percentage in use, page file spacing,
and any drives. It shows that these are fixed, E is a CD ROM,
and it will also show up network drives as being listed as actual network drives,
anything mapped out over a Microsoft or a Novell network.
Key logging is improved greatly.
You can log to any file anywhere you want.
And go ahead and fire up your logging.
And it shows that key logging has actually started.
And if you were to have something running on the target machine,
you could actually go back and, a great improvement on B02K is,
mkeystroke was always present, but you can now go through and actually view your keystroke log.
Instead of having to just do an actual view file, which would typically have problems
after three or four screens worth of text going on about a 25-plus screen,
the UDP connection would just kind of clog up and you would lose it.
Sometimes you'd actually have to repin the host or actually wait until it rebooted.
And you can see right here it said,
I control-skip to go to the start menu, open notepad,
it said testing key logging with several backspaces in it,
and then I just backed out and closed it off, and it actually said,
I just didn't know if that 4D wanted to save, and it actually does hit no for no,
and it does actually log that as well.
And then you can go through and go ahead and delete your keystroke log
if you find it to no longer be of use to you,
or if it's something that you've already shipped off to your administration
or worked on with any issues and you don't want anything sitting on your client machine.
On the GUI side of things, you can pop up the familiar system box
that looks as legitimate as anything with just the typical OK button,
and you've got your box title and any message you want to put inside it.
I'd show you, but I don't have the server up on the display,
so it's kind of pointless at this point.
Under TCP networking, we've got all the fun stuff.
The good old mapping a file server where you can give it a port,
and of course, if you're working through a firewall, chances are port 80 is going to be open,
so you can throw it on there, pass through a firewall.
Route path, you can usually leave blank, which will pull up a complete browser
of the entire machine, showing any local drives, network drives,
as well as the network neighborhood and any network resources it has mapped out.
You can use it to bounce a relay, like some kiddies like to do with Wingate,
where you can give it a port on this machine and give it an IP and a port on another one.
You can just go into your server, bounce out, and hit a second machine and port anywhere you want to.
And if you're creative, you can chain several of these together
and bounce between five or six of them.
It works good on a LAN, but anything outside that going over the net,
you're going to see a lot of lag on it.
Mapping port to a console application was similar to what was shown last year,
and in this case, I'll just grab a port 100 and run command.com.
And I can easily...
...telnet to the IP on the port.
And if it's going to work happily, which telnet on this is probably not going to work,
it would actually open up a telnet session that would give me basically a complete DOS prompt
on the other machine, and I would have full command line access to the whole hard drive
and any network resources that that client has available to it.
Because this machine is really buggy and has a lot of network components installed on it
that really want to conduce into this demo.
It's not my machine, so I'm kind of stuck.
You can also go ahead and just unmap any ports.
TcpFileReceive as well as TcpFileSend work in conjunction with Hobbit's Netcat,
and it does work really well and it's handy, but Netcat in itself should use at least an hour course.
It's a very full-featured item, and it's really fun to play with,
so you might want to look into grabbing that.
Otherwise, you can list any ports that are mapped out on the remote box
and right here you can see that we have port 100, which is shown as being listed over to command.com on it.
Microsoft Networking is very similar to last time.
You can add and remove shares on the remote machine,
and when you do so, it does not have the icon in Explorer that shows that it is shared.
You don't have the glue hand to it.
You just have a standard folder, and to the machine running the server,
as far as it's concerned, everything is plain and normal.
There's nothing odd or distinctly different going on with it.
It has DriveShare and it's completely oblivious to it.
I'll run through on that, but I don't have the sharing installed on the machine,
so we're unfortunately at a loss on it.
Yes?
Correct.
You can thank Microsoft for that one.
Because basically it would be the same as with the original back office.
There's nothing special that this is doing that was not included or considered when Windows was coded.
It's doing nothing.
There's no funny exploits that it's doing, short of any DLLs.
But the fact that you can have something shared without it showing as a share is a Microsoft issue.
Yes?
I believe it does.
Yes?
Essentially.
If you had it set to, if the machine could share the firewall on its own,
if you could add that machine, turn on sharing, and allow it to share through the firewall, then yes.
If the firewall was an issue blocking native sharing, then this would not be able to bypass that.
Yes.
And as with the original back office, you can pull up a list of all processes.
It actually does blank because I have nothing running on it right now.
All righty.
I was just notified that the remote machine ID is only for NT,
and we can leave it blank since we are connected directly to a single server right now.
And also I just went ahead and fired up Notepad on it since I actually had nothing running.
And you can see that we have Notepad down at the bottom.
B02K is showing because I do have it running visible.
I did not go through and do any of the cloaking or hiding on it.
And up above that, we have just a few of the standard MS issues that just sit there and hog resources all day long and don't do much.
You can pick any process that you would like to care.
And for instance, I can go right here and highlight and copy the ID of that process.
I can right-click and copy it.
I can go to pill process, paste it into the box.
It's in my command, and it now has been terminated.
And if we go back and check again,
we can see that Notepad is no longer running and B02K is the last entry.
So you do have full process control over whatever is going on in the remote machine.
Registry, you do have pretty much the same functionality as before.
You can go through and list keys.
You can view the files.
Values, you can delete the values.
Set and create keys completely from scratch.
This is kind of a tough way to do it.
You really need to know the registry and have RegEdit open on your machine
and hope you don't accidentally delete something on your side by accident with a bad mouse click.
However, I would like to show it to you right now, but I don't have it handy.
When B02K is released from Loft Heavy Industries, the RegEdit in that is absolutely phenomenal.
It opens a RegEdit box, which is just like running RegEdit on your local machine.
It's all point-and-click, and it's very easy to just click in something, edit a value.
You can surf around and view it as a tree.
You don't have to know exactly where everything resides.
But you do have full remote registry control,
and you do not have to have shared remote registry activated inside of the Microsoft Networking on the remote machine,
which is kind of a cluster in itself.
Again, we have any multimedia listings.
I have nothing running on this other machine, but you can easily list capture devices,
and it will list any microphones.
If I had the cam, I would have it plugged in right now, but it was left at home.
But you can plug in the cam on it, and I can easily go through, and that is listed as device zero.
And if I wanted to capture a video still or an AVI, I could give it my device number,
which in this case would have been zero instead of 100, give it a file name to save to,
and as an AVI, I would select the seconds and the width and the height and color depth of it.
And when you enter these values, it's the number followed by the comma followed by the next value.
You don't want to leave any spaces in, or it looks like it's not going to work for you.
If you were to search around using the file search, which we'll get to in a minute,
or if you're using Biotool and you search around and find some interesting WAV files,
or if you upload something to the machine, you can easily play them,
and you now have the nice annoying factor of being able to play them to you,
and just bug the heck out of somebody.
Remind your boss that you need a raise, maybe.
You can also, in addition to AVIs, capture a still, which will get you just a single picture
of the person sitting in front of the camera, or whatever happens to be going on in the office at that time.
Or you can capture a screen, which is also a simple capture of the desktop itself,
and you can download that through the HTTP server if you have that fired up,
or using Netcat and file transfer.
Under file and directory, we've got a lot of functions to play with.
You can list anything that resides inside of any file and path.
And here's everything pulled up.
And it actually has attributes that are listed to it,
so you can see if any files are hidden, if you want to hide or unhide a file.
You can change read and write attributes to anything.
Actually, attributes can be changed through Biotool, as well as through the attributes as well.
You can find files, and you can search off the root of any directory.
You can search through any path under a root of any drive on it.
Wildcards are accepted in file name, start.wav, start.gif.
Any .exe, if you have anything in particular you're looking for that you need to find or remove,
you have any full search spec that is available to you.
And once you find it, you can just go ahead and cut it and paste it in to the box
and delete any file you'd like to get rid of.
You have a view file, which works best on text documents.
I wouldn't recommend using it on any Microsoft Word documents or Excel sheets,
because it doesn't really look too pretty.
It does work well on text and on keystroke logs,
which is how you would actually previously view it if you didn't download it and view it locally.
You can move and rename files.
You can copy a file from one directory to another.
Make and remove directories, file attributes, sends and receives.
Emits, I'm actually not sure on.
And you can list any transfers that you have currently queued up that are in process.
And right now it should show as nothing because we have nothing going on.
But you do have full file access to the remote machine completely.
And you can, as we showed, go through and actually find,
find hidden and read-only files and change access to those however you feel fit
to take care of whatever you need to.
Again, also, if you do a capture to a BMP,
or if there's a large file on a server machine that you need to download to yourself,
you can freeze it, which basically is a compression.
And on a BMP that is normally about a meg and a half,
freezing typically drops it to about 300K.
So you can shrink things down and reduce your network traffic overall.
And if you're over a dial-up or a very limited pipe,
you can move large files that are compressed a lot quicker.
DNS, you can use the remote machine's DNS servers instead of your own
to pull up any information that you maybe have trouble to resolve
if your DNS is down or if you don't have anything of your own.
You can resolve host names on the remote machine as well as addresses
and do reverse lookups.
So that's a new feature that's kind of nice to play with.
If you find yourself using this to admin a large WAN in a corporate environment
where you have several offices across several cities or states
and you're having trouble with the machine on one end,
not being able to hit something, you could actually go into the remote machine
from your office and try to look up the target that he's trying to hit
and see if he does actually have a problem with his DNS
and try to troubleshoot it from there and figure out if it's actually a problem.
With the DNS server or his local DNS configuration.
Server control, you can shut down a server if you wanted to run it one time
but you just use your standard BR executable that you have running constantly.
You don't feel like running a new one, you can run it until you're done using it
and shut it down.
If you run it and type in delete, it will shut itself off and delete itself
with no trace that it was ever there.
You can restart the server, you can load and unload plugins,
you can debug plugins remotely.
You can list any plugins that are present.
And right here it says that we have both the TripleDes and BoPeep loaded.
You can start and kill off any command sockets associated with it.
Yes?
How do you install it on the server?
Yeah, you can upload it through the HTTP server or using file transfer.
You can upload it and dump it into a SQL and Windows system
and you can easily load it from inside server control.
And also BO2K does have support for the legacy buttplugs that were out initially
with ButtSniffer, the PacketSniffer, the ButtTrumpets and whatnot.
The original plugins are supported.
And the software development kit that is available with BO
is going to allow you to do a lot of the more functional ones
that take a lot of advantage of the newer functions built into BO2K.
Yes?
Yes?
I don't fully understand the question.
No, the DNS is strictly a matter of just doing a query on a DNS server.
Same as if you were to do something using one of the IP-based command lines
inside of Windows, like ping or trace route,
and it just basically does a DNS lookup.
It doesn't do anything other than lookups.
Yes?
Pardon?
You can dump route tables if you were to set up
bind a command like command.com to a port and turn it in.
You can look them up that way.
OPEAP, we're going to attempt to fire up here.
I'm going to set the frame rate rather low just initially
and then we can turn it up from there.
And ideally, it should fire up
which shows that the bitstream is started at the IP and at the port 15151
which we recall we looked at earlier when we put BO into the server and config utility.
One thing, in order to use DLLs,
you need to make sure that you have configured them inside your client as well.
Just right here we have triple-desk.
In order to use OPEAP, I will need to add it.
This is the same OPEAP DLL that we put into the server that we installed on the other machine.
You install it into your client.
And we can go through here in OPEAP.
And I'm going to leave all the settings the same.
We will need to go through again and change the encryption over to 3-desk.
From XOR, I'm going to set the value on that one.
And also on hijack, I will need to come down and change this to 3-desk as well.
And I'm also done.
And if all worked well, once we have BO running down on the server,
we can go to plug-ins.
You can see we now have a BOPEAP plug-in.
And when VO2 is released, you will have that listed down here.
And any other plug-ins that actually enhance the communication between the server and the client
will appear off this menu.
So theoretically, we should be able to hit the Bitstream Client.
And fire up Kinect.
And this will pull up everything that has already been pre-set into it.
And you can verify your settings of your port.
We are using TCP, and we did set it to 3-desk as well as the standard mall application.
And it's not happy with us.
And there we go.

And come up here.
And actually turn the frame rate up a bit.
And this does work best over LAN.
And we will connect again.
And you should notice some much more fluid movement on the remote machine.

Now once again we can connect.

And if I CTRL-XZ.
Select both of them first.
Click over.
I now have the red dot.
And as I move that over here.
I now have control of the remote desktop.
It looks kind of odd but what happens is where the red dot is at.
Represents where the mouse is actually sitting on the remote machine.
So I moved far off of my actual VidStream client window.

And we have full control over that as well as the remote keyboard.
When you fire this up.
You essentially lock out the remote keyboard.

You can from your desktop take over their machine.
Fix their problem for them.

And...
What it is we get paid for.

I know you can get up into the 300's and 400 ranges.

Especially since they didn't know what I was doing back all day long.
And this is just not being friendly with me today.
But basically if I wanted to have a window open.
I could actually type into it and the remote mouse and keyboard is completely locked out.
And renders it completely useless for the user.
So they can't interfere and ideally mess anything up too much for a window they already have.
If you're playing around with this at home.
A word of caution is to not let it go peep and hijack your own workstation.
Because your keyboard is not happy about trying to be locked out and controlling it at the same time.
I control Alt Z again and you can see where connect is now turned off.
And I resume control to the remote machine and I take control again of my own desktop.
So that is one of the cooler functions of it in my opinion.
You can also under connection details.
And it shows at the bottom we have the IP address and port of the machine.
The current time that's listed.
And as anything is going on over here.

So you get an idea as to how much you may or may not be clogging things up in the process.
And I'm going to dump that connection right now as well.
Also when you do have it fired up you do have a copy option.
So if you were to find a user doing something inappropriate.

Or anything that you deem useful you can snap a picture of their desktop to clipboard.
And paste it in the email and send it off to management in a memory way.
3Desk does not show up in the client because it's just a matter of encryption.
It's built into the running server.
And you've got it built in under your plugins.
So there's nothing that actually 3Desk would ever show up for.

And that's that.

Yeah.
That, to be truthful with you, I'm actually not entirely sure.
Okay.
You can set up an SSH tunnel and route through that.
Otherwise, there's not one heck of a lot you can do.
Because the whole purpose of masquerading is to block everything off.

I would pretty much stick with SSH.
I wouldn't want to consider anything else.
Because it would become a vulnerability at that point.
As it stands, is your root downloaded?
No.
But the way it is set up with the software development kit and the abilities of the plugins and whatnot, yes.
If somebody can write a plugin to do it, EO2K is capable of it.
You'll notice when we actually configured the server,
if you remember the original BO, you put in an IP,
either a range or just an actual IP address,
and a separate box for the port.
